page.title: 02LAND-USE NEAR BRECHIN
page.content: {Cereals}(mainly barley, with some wheat and oats) cover 48.5% of the farmland. The favourable natural environment and present high grain prices explain this dominance. Mixed {woodland}covers 14%. Some form shelter belts, some give privacy to mansions and some grow naturally in old limestone quarries worked a couple of centuries ago to lime the fields. {Rotation grass}for hay, silage or sheep and cattle grazing covers 14%. 8.5% has{potatoes}planted either for domestic use or for seed exports. {Oil seed rape,}for vegetable oils, occupies 6.5% of the land. {Turnips (2.8%) have declined because silage is cheaper and fewer animals are now raised. {Peas}are grown on 2.8% . {Permanent pastures}(only 1.8%) are mainly next to farm steadings. {Raspberries}at 0.9% are now rare.
